texts.label: text
texts.orig: It seems like lighttpd and Tomcat are at the forefront of what is ‘hot' these days. If you don't need the completeness of Apache on your server, you can use lighttpd to proxy to Tomcat, and it's pretty simple. This how-to will show you how to install lighttpd, Tomcat, and the Java JRE. Once they're installed it will also show you how to get lighttpd to use mod_proxy to connect to your Tomcat installation.
texts.text: It seems like lighttpd and Tomcat are at the forefront of what is ‘hot' these days. If you don't need the completeness of Apache on your server, you can use lighttpd to proxy to Tomcat, and it's pretty simple. This how-to will show you how to install lighttpd, Tomcat, and the Java JRE. Once they're installed it will also show you how to get lighttpd to use mod_proxy to connect to your Tomcat installation.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: First, some downloading has to be done. Grab the latest lighttpd RPM from rpmfind.net for your distribution. You will also need to pick up the latest version of  Tomcat  and the  Java JRE .
texts.text: First, some downloading has to be done. Grab the latest lighttpd RPM from rpmfind.net for your distribution. You will also need to pick up the latest version of  Tomcat  and the  Java JRE .

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Once all three of those are on the server, get them installed:
texts.text: Once all three of those are on the server, get them installed:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# rpm -Uvh lighttpd-1.3.16-1.2.el4.rf.i386.rpm
# tar xvzf apache-tomcat-6.0.10.tar.gz
# mv apache-tomcat-6.0.10 /usr/local/
# chmod +x jre-6u1-linux-i586.bin
# ./jre-6u1-linux-i586.bin
# mv jre1.6.0_01 /usr/local/
texts.text:
# rpm -Uvh lighttpd-1.3.16-1.2.el4.rf.i386.rpm
# tar xvzf apache-tomcat-6.0.10.tar.gz
# mv apache-tomcat-6.0.10 /usr/local/
# chmod +x jre-6u1-linux-i586.bin
# ./jre-6u1-linux-i586.bin
# mv jre1.6.0_01 /usr/local/

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Before you can do much else, you will need to set up your JAVA HOME and add JAVA HOME/bin to your path. Open up /etc/profile and add the following before the
texts.text: Before you can do much else, you will need to set up your JAVA HOME and add JAVA HOME/bin to your path. Open up /etc/profile and add the following before the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: export
texts.text: export

texts.label: text
texts.orig: statement:
texts.text: statement:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
JAVA_HOME="/usr/local/jre1.6.0_01/"
export JAVA_HOME
PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH
texts.text:
JAVA_HOME="/usr/local/jre1.6.0_01/"
export JAVA_HOME
PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH

texts.label: text
texts.orig: To make this change actually take effect, you will need to log out and become root again. Now, check that your JAVA_HOME is set:
texts.text: To make this change actually take effect, you will need to log out and become root again. Now, check that your JAVA_HOME is set:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# echo $JAVA_HOME
/usr/local/jre1.6.0_01/
texts.text:
# echo $JAVA_HOME
/usr/local/jre1.6.0_01/

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If the JAVA HOME is not set up, check your /etc/profile again. If it's set up, try starting Tomcat – there's no need to set the $CATALINA HOME, because Tomcat can figure it out on its own:
texts.text: If the JAVA HOME is not set up, check your /etc/profile again. If it's set up, try starting Tomcat – there's no need to set the $CATALINA HOME, because Tomcat can figure it out on its own:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# /usr/local/apache-tomcat-6.0.10/bin/startup.sh
Using CATALINA_BASE:   /usr/local/apache-tomcat-6.0.10
Using CATALINA_HOME:   /usr/local/apache-tomcat-6.0.10
Using CATALINA_TMPDIR: /usr/local/apache-tomcat-6.0.10/temp
Using JRE_HOME:       /usr/local/jre1.6.0_01/
texts.text:
# /usr/local/apache-tomcat-6.0.10/bin/startup.sh
Using CATALINA_BASE:   /usr/local/apache-tomcat-6.0.10
Using CATALINA_HOME:   /usr/local/apache-tomcat-6.0.10
Using CATALINA_TMPDIR: /usr/local/apache-tomcat-6.0.10/temp
Using JRE_HOME:       /usr/local/jre1.6.0_01/

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Try to connect to the server now on port 8080 and you should see a Tomcat default page. Now, go add a manager user to the $CATALINA_HOME/conf/tomcat-users.xml:
texts.text: Try to connect to the server now on port 8080 and you should see a Tomcat default page. Now, go add a manager user to the $CATALINA_HOME/conf/tomcat-users.xml:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
<role rolename="manager"/>
<user username="tomcat" password="password" roles="manager"/>
texts.text:
<role rolename="manager"/>
<user username="tomcat" password="password" roles="manager"/>

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Restart Tomcat for the changes to take effect:
texts.text: Restart Tomcat for the changes to take effect:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# /usr/local/apache-tomcat-6.0.10/bin/startup.sh
# /usr/local/apache-tomcat-6.0.10/bin/shutdown.sh
texts.text:
# /usr/local/apache-tomcat-6.0.10/bin/startup.sh
# /usr/local/apache-tomcat-6.0.10/bin/shutdown.sh

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Tomcat is ready to go, so it's time to configure lighttpd. Open the /etc/lighttpd/lighttpd.conf and activate mod_proxy by uncommenting it:

texts.orig: Drop to the bottom of the configuration file and add something like this, replacing your information as necessary:
texts.text: Drop to the bottom of the configuration file and add something like this, replacing your information as necessary:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Replace the IP address with a hostname or the correct IP for your server. This proxy directive makes lighttpd connect to Tomcat on the localhost on port 8080 whenever a request comes in on port 80 to lighttpd on the IP 10.10.10.56. Start lighttpd now and try it yourself!
texts.text: Replace the IP address with a hostname or the correct IP for your server. This proxy directive makes lighttpd connect to Tomcat on the localhost on port 8080 whenever a request comes in on port 80 to lighttpd on the IP 10.10.10.56. Start lighttpd now and try it yourself!
